questions.text: After cataract surgery; intraocular lens put uneventfully in a young patient what should be done then?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Never replaced In an uneventful intraocular lens placement, there is no indication to replace the IOL. An IOL replacement may done under the following conditions: Incorrect IOL placed Posterior or anterior dislocation of IOL Hyphema Sunset Syndrome Lens-Bag Decentration Asymmetrical Haptic Placement There is no indication to remove IOL after 10 years unless any complication like dislocation of IOL occurs. After development of a secondary cataract, we just treat it by laser; we don't remove IOL for this.

Highyeild:

COMPLICATIONS OF CATARACT SURGERY Operative complications Vitreous loss Posterior loss of lens fragments Suprachoroidal (expulsive) haemorrhage Early postoperative complications Iris prolapse Striate keratopathy Acute bacterial endophthalmitis Late postoperative complications Capsular opacification Implant displacement Corneal decompensation Retinal detachment Chronic bacterial endophthalmitis

Extraedge:

Three major cataract surgery procedures: Phacoemulsification. Femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS). Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE). Types of Intraocular Lenses (IOL) Monofocal Lenses:- These are standard lens implants that are designed to correct vision at one focal length. Toric Lenses:- These are designed to correct distance vision and extra built-in correction for astigmatism. Multifocal 10Ls:- This allows you to see both near and far objects . Some multifocal lenses can also correct intermediate vision. Trifocal IOLs:- This lens has only one corrective zone that is stretched to allow distance and intermediate vision. It uses light-splitting rings to elongate the depth of focus within the eye, giving a wider range of vision.

questions.text: When should Fundus examination be done in a 45 years old female with newly diagnosed diabetes mellitus with no visual symptoms?
questions.correct_answer: C. At the time of diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

At the time of diagnosis Screening should be done immediately because as person is 45 years old and, most probably, has type 2 DM For type 1 diabetes , screening for retinopathy is done 5 years after the diagnosis of diabetes. For type 2 diabetes , screening is done at the time of diagnosis of diabetes. As this patient is most probably having type 2 DM which has an occult onset and hence no particular information on the onset of the disease thus making it’s diagnosis at a later stage.

Highyeild:

Signs of Diabetic Retinopathy:- Retina thickening and edema (swelling) New blood vessels Hemorrhages Microaneurysms Cotton wool spots Hard exudates

Extraedge:

Pathophysiology DR is a microangiopathy primarily affecting the precapillary arterioles, capillaries , venules and post capillary venules. The basic components of the damaging process are microvascular occlusion & microvascular leakage. Capillary changes: Degeneration & loss of pericytes Thickening of Basement membrane Damage & proliferation of endothelial cells Hematological changes: Deformation of RBC & rouleaux formation Increased plasma viscosity Increased platelet stickiness & aggregation

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below:

options.label: A
options.text: It is called as Argyll Robertson pupil

options.label: B
options.text: This test is named after famous scientist Marcus gun, a physician of US.

options.label: C
options.text: The vision is normal in right eye

options.label: D
options.text: Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in both eyes in the presence of flash light.

questions.correct_answer: D. Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in both eyes in the presence of flash light.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in both eyes in the presence of flash light. The image suggests Marcus Gunn pupil/ relative afferent pupillary defect which is seen in optic neuritis. Marcus Gunn pupil refers to the paradoxical response of the pupil to light in the presence of a Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) It is confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response observed. Normally, both pupils should have remained constricted in the absence of any defect. In the presence of RAPD , when the flashlight is moved from the normal to the abnormal eye, both pupils dilate. Marcus Gunn pupil is a rare condition that affects the eyes, causing each to respond differently when a light is shone into This response indicates that there is dysfunction or disease in the optic nerve or retina . It is a type of relative afferent pupil defect (RAPD)

Highyeild:

Argyll Robertson Pupil AR Pupils are small (miosis), irregular in outline and have light near dissociation. They react poorly to light but very well to near reflex. AR Pupils are usually bilateral and symmetrical. Vision grossly intact. Causes of Optic Neuritis:- Marcus Gunn pupil is seen In optic neuritis. It is also common in retrobulbar optic neuritis due to multiple sclerosis but only for 3-4 weeks. Infection (e.g. syphilis, Lyme disease, herpes zoster), Autoimmune disorders (e.g. lupus, neurosarcoidosis, neuromyelitis optica), Inflammatory bowel disease, Drug induced (e.g.chloramphenicol, ethambutol, Isoniazid, streptomycin, quinine, penicillamine, Aminosalicylic acid, phenothiazine, phenylbutazone), Vitamin B12 deficiency Diabetes Mellitus

Extraedge:

Causes:- Disease Of Retina Retinal Detachment Retinal Ischemia Optic Nerve Disease Optic Neuritis Inflammation From Multiple Sclerosis Severe Glaucoma Trauma

questions.text: What is not to done in the given below case:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Remove the foreign body The above image shows penetrating injury with a metallic nail. Removal of metallic nail in Non OT setting will lead to leakage of intraocular contents. Hence, In the case of penetrating injuries , the foreign body should not be removed initially. Once the extent of the injury is ascertained by CT scan , the foreign body is removed under surgical exploration and repair. Metal nails should not be drawn out as it can cause gush of aqueous and can lead to pouring of intraocular contents along with it.

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stereopsis test The above image shows Titmus fly test used for diagnosis of stereopsis. This test presents three levels for testing young children. In each line, one of 4 symbols appears forward from the others. Stereopsis is a term used to refer to the perception of depth and 3-dimensional structure obtained on the basis of visual information from the 2 eyes. Stereo depth-perception tests, such as the Stereo Fly , have proven to be an effective and easy-to-use method of screening vision for all ages.

Highyeild:

Test For Stereopsis 1)The TNO stereo test 2) Lang Stereotest II(random dot) 3) Frisby Stereo Test 4) Titmus Fly Test (Polaroid vectograph)

Extraedge:

Stereopsis Physiology:- Depth may be perceived in two forms:- Binocular Disparity (stereopsis) Monocular Depth Cues Stereopsis is the perception of the relative depth of objects on the basis of binocular disparity which reflects the slight difference in the image presented to each eye
